titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: The United States Office of Scientific Research and Development (OSRD) was established in the Office for Emergency Management (OEM) by Executive Order in 1941. Its functions were to advise the President on the status of scientific and medical research relating to national defense, coordinate federal government research relating to national defense, and compile defense mobilization lists of scientific personnel and resources. The Office was abolished December 31, 1947. The bulk of the records of the Office and its Committees are held in the National Archives.

scopecontent.p: One of the committees working within the OSRD was the Committee on Medical Research, which worked on medical issues of concern to the military during World War II. Among the projects this committee worked on was the biosynthesis of penicillin. Some of the research for this project was conducted at Eli Lilly and Company laboratories. Joseph Corse was one of Eli Lily's researchers, and this collection consists of his copies of the progress reports issued by the committee, as well as memos, reprints of related journal articles and a copy of the main patent that resulted from the project. The collection also includes a copy of R.B. Woodward's second report to the Committee on Medical Research on the structure of penicillin.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

otherfindaid.p: An inventory is available in the repository.

relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found in the following collections: College of Physicians of Philadelphia: United States Office of Scientific Research and Development Committee on Medical Research Minutes, 1944-1946 (MSS 1/0003-01)
